headline: Ethereum Leads Risk-On Rally as Markets Warm

sections.the_session:
• Ethereum posted its strongest single-day performance in weeks, climbing 6.6% to reclaim $3,300 — a level that had served as stubborn resistance since early December, with the breakout accompanied by a notable uptick in spot volume on major exchanges.

• Bitcoin advanced 2.2% to $92,769, consolidating above the $90,000 psychological floor that had attracted dip buyers throughout the Asian session; the move lacked the urgency of ETH's rally but carried the steady bid characteristic of institutional accumulation windows.

• BTC dominance slipped to 56.8% as capital rotated into alts, with Solana gaining 3.8% to $138 — the kind of broad-based strength that typically signals improving risk appetite rather than isolated speculation.

• Total crypto market capitalisation expanded to $3.26 trillion, adding roughly $80 billion in 24 hours; the Fear & Greed Index edged back toward neutral territory after spending much of last week in cautious mode.
sections.the_session_title: ETH Outpaces Bitcoin in Broad Risk Recovery
sections.the_macro:
• The dollar index retreated 0.3% ahead of tomorrow's FOMC minutes release, providing a tailwind for risk assets including crypto; traders are parsing whether December's hawkish hold will be reinforced or softened by the committee's internal debate.

• US equity markets closed mixed with the S&P 500 flat and Nasdaq up 0.4%, as tech strength offset weakness in defensive sectors — the rotation pattern that has historically correlated with crypto's better days.

• Treasury yields held steady with the 10-year at 4.58%, offering no fresh catalyst but maintaining the elevated rate environment that continues to shape institutional allocation decisions toward digital assets.

• European Central Bank officials signalled patience on rate cuts despite softening inflation data, keeping the transatlantic monetary divergence narrative alive and supporting dollar-denominated asset flows.
sections.the_macro_title: Fed Minutes Loom as Dollar Softens

north_america.name: North America
north_america.content:
• US spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded estimated net inflows of $287 million on Tuesday, with BlackRock's IBIT capturing the lion's share at approximately $190 million — extending a pattern of concentrated flows into the market leader that has defined January trading.

• Fidelity's FBTC added an estimated $65 million while Grayscale's GBTC saw modest outflows of $23 million, the latter's bleeding having slowed considerably from the aggressive redemptions that marked its first weeks as a spot product.

• The SEC remained quiet on pending altcoin ETF applications, though industry sources suggest the agency is conducting preliminary reviews of Solana and XRP filings submitted in late 2024 — a process that could stretch well into Q2.

• Canadian regulators proposed new guidance on stablecoin reserves, requiring issuers to hold 100% backing in cash or short-term government securities; the rules would align Canada more closely with emerging EU standards under MiCA.

• Marathon Digital reported a 12% increase in January hash rate, reaching 28.7 EH/s as the miner's Texas facilities came fully online following winter grid stabilisation.

central_america.name: Central America
central_america.content:
• El Salvador's Bitcoin Office published its latest proof-of-reserves showing 6,044 BTC in the national treasury, valued at approximately $561 million at current prices — President Bukele has maintained the accumulation strategy despite IMF pressure to scale back.

• Guatemala's central bank issued a reminder that Bitcoin remains outside the regulated financial system, a routine statement that nonetheless followed reports of growing Lightning Network adoption among remittance corridors serving US-based workers.

• Panama's crypto regulatory framework remains in legislative limbo, with the bill stalled since late 2024; local exchanges report steady volume but cite uncertainty as a barrier to institutional partnerships.

south_america.name: South America
south_america.content:
• Brazil's securities regulator CVM approved two new crypto index funds for retail distribution, expanding access beyond the spot Bitcoin ETFs that launched last year; both products track broad market indices rather than single assets.

• Argentine peso weakness accelerated with the unofficial dollar rate breaching 1,200 pesos, driving renewed interest in USDT and USDC on local platforms; Lemon Cash reported a 15% week-over-week increase in stablecoin purchases.

• Colombia's financial superintendent met with Binance executives to discuss compliance frameworks, part of an ongoing dialogue that could result in the exchange obtaining a formal operating licence by mid-2025.

• Venezuela's Sunacrip, the state crypto regulator, announced plans to expand the Petro's use in public sector salary payments — though adoption remains negligible outside government-mandated transactions.

image_keywords: Manhattan skyline, golden sunset, Hudson River, warm evening glow
